item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Sensor Arm Light Bulb
item.description:
During the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5513), I inspected the sensor arm light bulb and was surprised to find it in perfect condition. Unlike other bulbs I’ve encountered, which typically display a dark film on the glass due to filament evaporation, this one was spotless: This suggests that this particular Beogram was either lightly used or had its bulb replaced previously. As a result, I will not change it. However, the bulb’s placement within its compartment is worth noting...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-sensor-arm-light-bulb/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Power Supply and Replacing the Reservoir Capacitors with a 3D Printed Fixture
item.description:
It seems Bang & Olufsen made two versions of the Beogram 4002 (5513) with different power supply setups, both designed with a possible CD4 upgrade in mind. The output board could be swapped for one with a pre-amplifier and CD4 decoder. One version powers the CD4 board directly from the main PCB’s 30V rail and uses a single 4000uF capacitor. My Beogram 4002 uses a separate power supply for the CD4 board, with its own transformer winding, bridge rectifier, and 1000uF capacitor...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-power-supply-and-replacing-the-reservoir-capacitors-with-a-3d-printed-fixture/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Speed Indictor Light Bulbs with RGB LEDs
item.description:
During the wait for a 3D-printed part for a Beogram 4002 turntable restoration, the author decided to upgrade its speed indicator lights. Using a method from a previous video, they replaced the incandescent bulbs with RGB LEDs for a more authentic look. The original setup with incandescent bulbs was documented before the upgrade. The new setup utilizes both the red and green diodes of an RGB LED for a natural appearance, addressing the issue of amber LEDs failing to illuminate red scale markers properly...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-replacing-the-speed-indictor-light-bulbs-with-rgb-leds/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors on the PCBs
item.description:
I began restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) by replacing all the electrolytic capacitors on the printed circuit boards with high-quality 105C capacitors. I made sure to use components from reputable Japanese brands like Nichicon and Rubycon, sourcing them through trusted distributors like Newark and Mouser. The process was straightforward, aside from uncovering a spider web (and its architect) beneath the main PCB. This restoration project also highlighted the existence of at least two different solenoid control circuits within the 5513 series...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-replacing-the-electrolytic-capacitors-on-the-pcbs/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Re-Attaching Keypad Segments
item.description:
My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is moving along, and I’m currently focusing on aesthetics. The last step was to reattach two keypad sections that had become unglued. The image illustrates the problem: I used a small amount of superglue gel and clamped the pads down with vise grips: It’s important to use minimal glue to avoid damaging the delicate paint on the pad’s surface. Start with a small amount and add more if needed...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-re-attaching-keypad-segments/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): First Contact and Test Drive
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable in good condition that needed some attention. I connected it to my Beosystem 6000 to test it, but a loud hum started immediately when I turned on the Beomaster 6000. Upon closer inspection, I discovered that P9 on the printed circuit board was installed backward. This connector isn’t polarized, so it can be inserted either way. Fortunately, this doesn’t cause damage because the connector doesn’t carry any power...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-first-contact-and-test-drive/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the DIN 5 Cable with a Cable Featuring RCA Plugs
item.description:
I am rebuilding a Beogram 4002(5513) turntable to use with a McIntosh Preamplifier. The standard DIN5 connector on Bang & Olufsen equipment is incompatible, so I am replacing it with RCA connectors for the best shielding and lowest EMI. Direct installation inside the turntable offers superior performance compared to adapters. For optimal sound, I chose high-quality, open-ended RCA cables from Sounds Heavenly in the UK. These cables feature individually shielded, twisted-pair left and right channels, embodying an “audiophile” design...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-replacing-the-din-5-cable-with-a-cable-featuring-rca-plugs/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Cabinet Repair and Guiding Washers Installation
item.description:
While waiting for audio cables from Sounds Heavenly, I decided to fix up the wooden case of my Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. Both corners were cracked, and the plastic washers that guide the sliding mechanism were gone. The first picture shows one of the damaged corners. [Image of a cracked turntable cabinet] Repairing the cracks was simple. Since the case is held together with metal bands, I glued the wood pieces and clamped them until the glue dried...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-cabinet-repair-and-guiding-washers-installation/

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Test Drive with Herbie Hancock (Secrets)
item.description:
I’m thrilled to share that I just got my hands on a nearly perfect copy of Herbie Hancock’s 1976 album “Secrets.” It’s in such great condition, it practically looks untouched! This album holds a special place in my heart, especially the track “People Music” with its captivating atmospheric interludes and those classic 70s analog synthesizer sounds, likely created on a “Maestro Universal Synthesizer System.” To celebrate, I decided to listen to the record on my newly restored Beogram 4002(5513) turntable, which is temporarily hooked up to my Beomaster 6000 4-Channel receiver for testing...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/beogram-4002-5513-test-drive-with-herbie-hancock-secrets-/
